Posts.Content: Dr Snuffy Myers claims positive, sometimes curative, results when there are fewer than five nodes involved. As to the standard scans, by the time the cancer shows it has been working for some time. Myers and other specialists now use some scans that show the cancer much sooner. I suggest you seeks out an excellent prostate cancer oncologist immediately. I would also suggest investigating hormone therapy while the cancer is minimal. It can begin before the radiation and will both weaken the cancer that will be radiated and that which the radiation can not reach if it has spread. It is now more the domain of the oncologist.
Posts.Title: Need Guidance

Posts.Content: I was G7 and T2b and chose High Dose brachytherapy and IMRT. The HDR is the version of brachytherapy that uses a temporary high dose implant and does not leave the seeds in the body. I chose it for the improved accuracy of radiation delivery and fewer side effects. Like Grappler I wanted to avoid surgery and checked out all the options including permanent seeds with another guru, Frank Critz here in Atlanta. My urologist suggested HDR instead of surgery because of the Partin and nomograms he worked on specific to my cancer. He and my rad-onc have done more than 1,000 of the HDR procedures and their practices have been doing HDR for more than 10 years. I completed therapy on 12-23-2010 and am free of side effects. I have not had urinary, bowell, or sex problems. I was a little tender from the procedure for a few days but did not limit any activities. Throughout the treatment period I missed three days of work and one was for a colonoscopy. For details, check out HDR at www.cetmc.net run by Dr Jeffrey Demanes. He has been doing HDR since 1981 and publishes 15 year statistics. He runs the rad-onc for prostatre cancer at UCLA. I would strongly suggest you research the radiation method (both permanent seeds and HDR) as the long term results are on par with surgery and the side effects are normally fewer and less serious.
Posts.Title: New Poster: Received my Brachytherapy yesterday:10/04/10

Posts.Content: Take john T's advice very serioulsy. You have read Dr Walsh's book and you need to understand clearly that he would not operate on you. You are too high risk and would ruin his success ratio. I was in the same boat, being high risk. My urologist would not operate as he did not think it would be curative. He believed I would need radiation in addition to surgery and he would not subject me to the additional risks and side effects of surgery and radiation when surgery would not solve the problem. The thought that you can use radiation as a back up is a red herring excuse to operate. Salvage radiation is used to reach the cancer the surgery could not get. But the damage to the nerves has already been suffered from the surgery. Start with radiation as it will eradicate the cancer as effective or more so than surgery and will get all the areas the surgery misses from the start. Before you make any decisions, see at least two radiation oncologists that do both brachytherapy and external beam. You should also see a medical oncologist that specializes in prostate cancer. You are high risk and a urologist alone will not be suffecient. For brachytherapy radiation research use the following websites: for Hoigh Dose Rate brachytherapy www.cetmc,com, the website of Dr jeffrey Demanes the HDR pioneer that heads the brachytherapy department at UCLA. For permanent seedts use www.prostrcision.com the website of Dr Frank Critz whi pioneered the use of IMRT and adjuvant permanent seeds. Both methods are better for advanced high risk cancer than surgery and leave far less side effects. I was PSA 59, 12 of 12 cores positive, and G7. I started with ADT3 (casodex, lupron, and jalyn), did 30 sessions of IMRT, and had two HDR brachytherapy sessions. Nearly two years later my PSA is undectible, I pee when I want (no pads), and sex is fine.

Posts.Title: New Poster: Received my Brachytherapy yesterday:10/04/10

Posts.Content: Also go to drinking clear liquids. Eliminate caffine, acid rich drinks like orange juice, and carbonated drinks. Often these will cause urinary distress. I also doubled up on Flomax at times and it was fine.
Posts.Title: Symptoms after Brachytheraphy...help.

Posts.Content: Glad to hear you have done well. I am now four months out from the procedure and am doing great. All side effects of the HDR are gone. I am sure you will do well. I also encourage people to seriously consider HDR.
Posts.Title: HDR Monotherapy - anybody with some experience with this treatment?

Posts.Content: I had HDR procedures December 6 amd 13, 2010. I had it in conjunction with IMRT and HT as I am higher risk than you. You look like a great mono candidate according to Demanes' information on his website. I am very happy that I used HDR and I am in Atlanta where the premier permanent seed clinic is. I looked at them but between Demanes and my med-onc I bought into the better accuracy and fewer side effects of HDR. My procedures were well tolerated. My side effects from the first procedure was basically painful urination for two days. The second time they used a different preparation for the catheter and there was no burning. Sitting on hard chairs was tough for about three weeks as it felt like I was sittting on a golf ball. There is a little bit of internal bleeding and the blood follows gravity. For about three weeks my penis and scrotum were black and swollen.....looked pretty wierd. This went away after a few weeks. For the physical aspects a little pain relief was good as well as a warm bath each evening. I was on a number of meds for awhile. Levaquin was used to ward off any infection. I was on a steroid for six days to reduce swelling. Also UTA to numb the urinry tract and Flomax to help the flow. No ED, but the first several ejaculation were dark brown. Volume is also reduced, but sex works well and enjoyable. I am guessing that the dark semen will stop pretty soon. Overall, all went well. Also remember that I was undergoing IMRT so I was at greater risk of side effects than you will be with monotherapy. I would strongly sugggest HDR and you are with two of the pioneers. My urologist and rad-onc have done about 1,000 as a team and have the system down pat. They are both young, uro is 43 and rad-onc is late 30's. I had my first round of visits over the last two weeks, saw my rad-onc today. I am two months post treatment and first PSA was <0.10. Remember that I am on HT so this is to be expected. When I told my oncologist I was considering HDR he said ..."great...permanent seeds are last century...HDR is 21st century....more accurate, more effective, and less side effects." Best wishes and let me know in any way I can help, Jack

AgeInfo.Phrase: are both young  uro is 43 and rad onc is late

Posts.Title: HDR Monotherapy - anybody with some experience with this treatment?

Posts.Content: Glad to hear you have done well. I am now four months out from the procedure and am doing great. All side effects of the HDR are gone. I am sure you will do well. I also encourage people to seriously consider HDR.
Posts.Title: HDR Monotherapy - anybody with some experience with this treatment?

Posts.Content: I used high dose radiation brachytherapy for a number of reasons. As I understand, it allows for a more conformal dose of radiation both in shape and strength to deliver a more effective radiation cloud with reduced side effects, it delivers a very high dose in a short period of time that can have a different kill effect when compared to the low dose, and it does not leave the pellets in the body. First it does this by using CT scanning to confirm and adjust the delivery catheter placements before the radiation is introduced. I had 15 catheters inserted. This improves on the placement compared to using ultrasound only which can be a few mm off in accuracy. Second, the radiation pellet is delivered through each catheter based on a calculated dwell time. The length of time the pellet stays in any one position determines the radiation dose delivered in that position. This can be different different among the catheters and within any catheter. Thus, more dose can be more specifically tailored to where the docs want it delivered. Third, since the HDR is delivered in multiple procedures (mine was in two procedures one week apart) the rad-onc and urologist can change the approach each time to meet the treatment plan. Since the pellets are not left in the body, there is no possible seed migration or unintended radiation delivery resulting from the body's normal changes over the long period of time the permanent pellets are radioactive. Weight gain or loss, fluid retention changes, prostate size changes, and other changes over the many months the permanent pellets are radioactive can change the delivery dose from what was intended and cause hot and cold spots which can reduce effectiveness and increase side effects. My med-onc supports HDR over permanent seeds based on improved technology and accuracy. He said "permanent seeds are last century....HDR is 21st century". You might think of it like open surgery versus robotic surgery. Some of the best information I found to make my decision is at www.cetmc.com. The site is that of Jeffrey Demanes, the HDR pioneer that runs brachytherapy at UCLA. HDR brachytherapy is also used for many other cancers than just prostate cancer including breast, head and neck, lung, soft tissue, bile duct, and women's reproductive organ cancers. Also check the Prostate Cancer Research Institute (www.prostate-cancer.org) website as there are several papers on HDR. Demanes is a featured speaker at the Prostate Cancer Conference in September in LA.
Posts.Title: HDR Monotherapy - anybody with some experience with this treatment?

Posts.Content: It is a Red Herring regarding no surgery after radiation that didn't work. If the radiation didn't work the surgery would not have worked either as surgery removes a much smaller area than radiation can cover. Brachytherapy and IMRT have proven to be as effective as surgery in lower risk cases and in intermediate and advanced cases more effective than surgery and with less onerous side effects. Major radiation clinics have 10 and 15 year experience statistics. On another website there is a compilation of several thousands of studies that indicate the effectiveness. I will retrieve it and add to a post. Major institutions like Johns Hopkins and MSK have been much more surgicaly oriented over the years and thus have more statistical history for surgery. The advancements in radiation in the last ten years have greatly improved the effectiveness and reduced the side effects. Before you decide on treatment seek several different opinions from both methods and see a medical oncologist who will neither operate nor radiate. Rule of thumb is that in the low risk cases use the method that results in the least side effects. In intermediate and high risk cases seek the method that gives the best cancer control. I was high risk and my surgeon-urologist said no surgery as it wouldn't be effective. He advised HDR Brachytherapy and IMRT. After several other opinions I agreed with his assessment and was so treated.
Posts.Title: Diagnosed 5 days ago. Still in the fog stage. Could use some support.

Posts.Content: Here is the link to the compliation of some 18,000 studies of effectiveness and side effects of all the treatment methods. It is in Insights, the quarterly newsletter of the Prostate Cancer Research Institute. If the link doesn't work, go to www.prostate-cancer.org, click on Insights and look for the May 2011 issue Vol 14, number 2. The article is by Dr. Peter Grimm and is titled "Long Term Outcomes for Prostate Cancer Therapy Choices". Excellent reading and it should be required for the newly diagnosed like you. http://prostate-cancer.org/PDFs/Is14-2_p3-11.pdf

Posts.Title: HDR Monotherapy - anybody with some experience with this treatment?

Posts.Content: I had HDR procedures December 6 amd 13, 2010. I had it in conjunction with IMRT and HT as I am higher risk than you. You look like a great mono candidate according to Demanes' information on his website. I am very happy that I used HDR and I am in Atlanta where the premier permanent seed clinic is. I looked at them but between Demanes and my med-onc I bought into the better accuracy and fewer side effects of HDR. My procedures were well tolerated. My side effects from the first procedure was basically painful urination for two days. The second time they used a different preparation for the catheter and there was no burning. Sitting on hard chairs was tough for about three weeks as it felt like I was sittting on a golf ball. There is a little bit of internal bleeding and the blood follows gravity. For about three weeks my penis and scrotum were black and swollen.....looked pretty wierd. This went away after a few weeks. For the physical aspects a little pain relief was good as well as a warm bath each evening. I was on a number of meds for awhile. Levaquin was used to ward off any infection. I was on a steroid for six days to reduce swelling. Also UTA to numb the urinry tract and Flomax to help the flow. No ED, but the first several ejaculation were dark brown. Volume is also reduced, but sex works well and enjoyable. I am guessing that the dark semen will stop pretty soon. Overall, all went well. Also remember that I was undergoing IMRT so I was at greater risk of side effects than you will be with monotherapy. I would strongly sugggest HDR and you are with two of the pioneers. My urologist and rad-onc have done about 1,000 as a team and have the system down pat. They are both young, uro is 43 and rad-onc is late 30's. I had my first round of visits over the last two weeks, saw my rad-onc today. I am two months post treatment and first PSA was <0.10. Remember that I am on HT so this is to be expected. When I told my oncologist I was considering HDR he said ..."great...permanent seeds are last century...HDR is 21st century....more accurate, more effective, and less side effects." Best wishes and let me know in any way I can help, Jack

This improves on the placement compared to using ultrasound only which can be a few mm off in accuracy. Second, the radiation pellet is delivered through each catheter based on a calculated dwell time. The length of time the pellet stays in any one position determines the radiation dose delivered in that position. This can be different different among the catheters and within any catheter. Thus, more dose can be more specifically tailored to where the docs want it delivered. Third, since the HDR is delivered in multiple procedures (mine was in two procedures one week apart) the rad-onc and urologist can change the approach each time to meet the treatment plan. Since the pellets are not left in the body, there is no possible seed migration or unintended radiation delivery resulting from the body's normal changes over the long period of time the permanent pellets are radioactive. Weight gain or loss, fluid retention changes, prostate size changes, and other changes over the many months the permanent pellets are radioactive can change the delivery dose from what was intended and cause hot and cold spots which can reduce effectiveness and increase side effects. My med-onc supports HDR over permanent seeds based on improved technology and accuracy. He said "permanent seeds are last century....HDR is 21st century". You might think of it like open surgery versus robotic surgery. Some of the best information I found to make my decision is at www.cetmc.com. The site is that of Jeffrey Demanes, the HDR pioneer that runs brachytherapy at UCLA. HDR brachytherapy is also used for many other cancers than just prostate cancer including breast, head and neck, lung, soft tissue, bile duct, and women's reproductive organ cancers. Also check the Prostate Cancer Research Institute (www.prostate-cancer.org) website as there are several papers on HDR. Demanes is a featured speaker at the Prostate Cancer Conference in September in LA.
Posts.Title: HDR Monotherapy - anybody with some experience with this treatment?

Posts.Content: Glad to hear you have done well. I am now four months out from the procedure and am doing great. All side effects of the HDR are gone. I am sure you will do well. I also encourage people to seriously consider HDR.
Posts.Title: HDR Monotherapy - anybody with some experience with this treatment?

Posts.Content: I was in a similar situation two years ago with PSA 59, palpable one centimeter nodule, and all 12 cores positive with 3+3, 3+4, and 4+3. Scans didntr show anything, but three uros, two rad-oncs, and one med-onc all said high risk and advised to hit it hard. I started with ADT3, then IMRT and HDR brachytherapy. Two years later, and still on ADT, my PSA is undectible (just got another <.1 from Bostwick this week). My exprience and research indicates that you probably need to get on this and hit it from multiple directions to weeken it and get a long and durable remission. Seek out practitioners that see high risk cases all the time. You don't want to be the most advanced a doctor has seen. First questions from me would be..."tell me about the five worst cases you have treated, how did you treat them, and how are they doing?"
Posts.Title: Applying For Membership And Seeking Advice

Posts.Content: It is a Red Herring regarding no surgery after radiation that didn't work. If the radiation didn't work the surgery would not have worked either as surgery removes a much smaller area than radiation can cover. Brachytherapy and IMRT have proven to be as effective as surgery in lower risk cases and in intermediate and advanced cases more effective than surgery and with less onerous side effects. Major radiation clinics have 10 and 15 year experience statistics. On another website there is a compilation of several thousands of studies that indicate the effectiveness. I will retrieve it and add to a post. Major institutions like Johns Hopkins and MSK have been much more surgicaly oriented over the years and thus have more statistical history for surgery. The advancements in radiation in the last ten years have greatly improved the effectiveness and reduced the side effects. Before you decide on treatment seek several different opinions from both methods and see a medical oncologist who will neither operate nor radiate. Rule of thumb is that in the low risk cases use the method that results in the least side effects. In intermediate and high risk cases seek the method that gives the best cancer control. I was high risk and my surgeon-urologist said no surgery as it wouldn't be effective. He advised HDR Brachytherapy and IMRT. After several other opinions I agreed with his assessment and was so treated.
Posts.Title: Diagnosed 5 days ago. Still in the fog stage. Could use some support.

Posts.Content: I was in a similar situation two years ago with PSA 59, palpable one centimeter nodule, and all 12 cores positive with 3+3, 3+4, and 4+3. Scans didntr show anything, but three uros, two rad-oncs, and one med-onc all said high risk and advised to hit it hard. I started with ADT3, then IMRT and HDR brachytherapy. Two years later, and still on ADT, my PSA is undectible (just got another <.1 from Bostwick this week). Seek out practitioners that see high risk cases all the time. You don't want to be the most advanced a doctor has seen. First questions from me would be..."tell me about the five worst cases you have treated, how did you treat them, and how are they doing?"
Posts.Title: Applying For Membership And Seeking Advice

Posts.Content: The "Gold Standard" was proclaimed by surgeons that operated on G6 PSA 4 men who should have not done anything. For God's sake, a stage 3 says it is already out of the capsule and surgery won't be curative. IMRT and brachytherapy will do the best for you....maybe some ADT thrown in. But surgery is ridiculous at this point. Seek the advice of a rad-onc and med-onc, not just a uro-surgeon. Why ask for incontinence and impotence when it is not the solution?
Posts.Title: Staging Results And A Few More Questions

Posts.Content: I used HDR and based my research on Dr Demanes. His website is www.cetmc.com. I am Atlanta and had two clinics to choose from for HDR so I did not travel to UCLA.
Posts.Title: Photon vs hdr

Posts.Content: I agree with Newporter. As I understand, the radiation bounce is typically in the 18-36 month range after seeing the PSA steadily decline. Your PSA looks to be steadily increasing just after radiation. I would seek another opinion. There is some great information about PSA post-radiation bounce on www.prostrcision.com, the website of Dr Frank Critz. He pioneered LDR Brachytherapy and Adjuvant IMRT and his clinic has treated more than 15,000 men. He has very good information explaining what the PSA should do after treatment and how the bounce shows up.
Posts.Title: PSA Bounce after combination IGRT/Brachytherapy

Posts.Content: You are high risk, as was I. My uro would not operate because the nomograms indicated a very high probability that surgery would not be curative. He was not going to subject me to the risks and side effects of both surgery and radiation. I had a combination of High Dose rate brachytherapy and IMRT external beam radiotherapy. Added to this is a three year course of hormone therapy. So far my PSA has gone from 59 to <.1 in the first 100 days. I am approaching two years fom the radiation and have no side effects or problems with urinary, bowel, or sexual functions. The above advise is excellent and indicates that you should seek multiple opinions from urologists, radiologists, and medical oncologists. JohnT's point about the nerve bundles is very important.
Posts.Title: This sure is happening fast!

Posts.Content: PSA that high has a very high probability of being cancer. I was PSA 59 and my GP rushed me to an urologist who did a DRE and felt a nodule. He then scheduled a biopsy that did prove to be PCa. That was nearly two years ago and my treatment has been very effective and with few side effects. I have used a combination of brachytherapy, external beam radiation, and hormone therapy (no surgery). My PSA deopped to undectible within 90 days an has stayed there since. One step at a time and stay calm. Start your research so you don't have any surprises and understand that there are a lot of very effective treatments for PCa. Best wishes and please keep us informed, jack
Posts.Title: help! newbie

Posts.Content: PSA that high has a very high probability of being cancer. I was PSA 59 and my GP rushed me to an urologist who did a DRE and felt a nodule. Posts.Title: help! newbie

Posts.Content: First you have to determine whether Proton Beam radiation is the most appropriate for your treatment based on your cancer. Due to the narrow beam it is not as effective for intermediate, advanced, multi-focal, or to cover the areas just outside the gland. The IMRT/IGRT are generally better for these situations. Even where Proton Beam is indicated it has not proven to be any bettter than IMRT/IGRT in cancer effectiveness and it about three times as expensive. We are seeing more insurance companies declining to cover Proton Beam due to it's higher cost and similar effectiveness.
Posts.Title: proton beam therapy for prostate cancer

Posts.Content: I want to second the motion that you also also consider brachytherapy radiation before you decide what to do. The treatment success is the same with surgery or radiation, but the radiation has fewer and less severe side effects. With brachytherapy you can choose between low dose permanent seed radiation and high dose temporary radiation. I went with the HDR and am very pleased with the procedure and results. In all, I missed two days of work due to HDR and I also had 25 IMRT sessions. You look like an excelent candidate for HDR. Check out how it works at www.cetmc.com, the website of Jeffrey Demanes, the HDR pioneer that is the head of brachytherapy at UCLA.

AgeInfo.Phrase: HDR and I also had 25 IMRT sessions <Z> <Z> <Z>

Posts.Title: Choosing A Surgeon For da Vinci Robotic Prostatectomy

Posts.Content: I am on Eligard (similar to Lupron) because I should have a 15 or more year life expectancy as I am 61. Without the treatment I probably would live 7-10 years so the side effects for a few years are worth it. But at 96 the situation is far different. You give no other information as to how advanced your father's cancer is or how he has been treated in the past. What is the reason for his weight loss now? I don't see how Lupron is going to significantly extend the life of a 96 year old in such a way that the side effects are worth the extension. Get another doctor and please provide more details of your dad's condition.

Posts.Title: help! newbie

Posts.Content: Always be careful. A friend fought PCa for 7 years before his passing last year. They threw everything at him but to no avail. It finally it mutated into small cellPCa in his lungs. His PSA was never over 10! Not normal, but what is?
